books.author: Hans Christian Andersen
books.title: Fairy tales
books.about: A collection of enchanting and often poignant fairy tales, including classics like 'The Little Mermaid,' 'The Ugly Duckling,' and 'The Emperor's New Clothes,' which blend fantasy, moral lessons, and explorations of human emotions such as love, sacrifice, identity, and vanity.

books.author: Samuel Beckett
books.title: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable, the trilogy
books.about: A groundbreaking modernist trilogy exploring existential despair, identity, and the limits of language through unreliable, decaying narrators—Molloy on a futile quest, Malone awaiting death while storytelling, and the disembodied Unnamable struggling with self and existence.

books.author: Giovanni Boccaccio
books.title: The Decameron
books.about: A frame narrative of ten young people fleeing the Black Death in Florence who tell one hundred tales over ten days, covering love, wit, tragedy, fortune, and human folly in a vibrant, often bawdy celebration of storytelling and life's resilience.

books.author: Emily Brontë
books.title: Wuthering Heights
books.about: A dark Gothic novel of passionate, destructive love between Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw on the Yorkshire moors, spanning generations and exploring themes of revenge, class, obsession, the supernatural, and the wild forces of nature and emotion.

books.author: Paul Celan
books.title: Poems
books.about: A collection of profound, elliptical poetry marked by Holocaust trauma, linguistic innovation, and dense imagery, grappling with memory, loss, silence, Jewish identity, and the limits of language in expressing atrocity and survival.

books.author: Louis-Ferdinand Céline
books.title: Journey to the End of the Night
books.about: A semi-autobiographical modernist novel following Ferdinand Bardamu through World War I, colonial Africa, and Depression-era America and France, delivering a raw, cynical critique of war, colonialism, racism, poverty, and human hypocrisy in stream-of-consciousness style.

books.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
books.title: The Canterbury Tales
books.about: A frame narrative of pilgrims traveling to Canterbury Cathedral who tell varied tales—romantic, bawdy, moral, and satirical—revealing medieval English society, human nature, class, gender, religion, and storytelling across genres.

books.author: Joseph Conrad
books.title: Nostromo
books.about: Set in the fictional South American country of Costaguana, this political novel examines greed, corruption, revolution, imperialism, and moral compromise through the story of the silver mine and characters like the idealistic Nostromo and the cynical journalist Decoud.

books.author: Charles Dickens
books.title: Great Expectations
books.about: A coming-of-age story of orphan Pip, whose life changes with mysterious benefactions, exploring themes of social class, ambition, guilt, redemption, love, and the illusions of gentility in Victorian England.

books.author: Denis Diderot
books.title: Jacques the Fatalist
books.about: A playful, metafictional Enlightenment novel in dialogue form following servant Jacques and his master on a journey, filled with digressions, interruptions, and philosophical debates on fate, free will, storytelling, and determinism.

books.author: Alfred Döblin
books.title: Berlin Alexanderplatz
books.about: A modernist masterpiece depicting the chaotic life of ex-convict Franz Biberkopf in Weimar-era Berlin, blending stream-of-consciousness, newspaper clippings, and urban realism to explore poverty, crime, politics, fate, and the overwhelming modern city.

books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.about: A psychological thriller following impoverished student Raskolnikov, who murders an exploitative pawnbroker to test his theory of extraordinary individuals above morality, leading to intense guilt, paranoia, redemption, and philosophical debates on crime, conscience, and salvation.

books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.title: The Idiot
books.about: The story of Prince Myshkin, an innocent, Christ-like epileptic returning to Russia, whose pure goodness clashes with a corrupt, cynical society, exploring themes of compassion, beauty, epilepsy, love triangles, and the possibility of true virtue in a fallen world.

books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.title: The Possessed
books.about: Also known as Demons or The Devils, this political novel satirizes revolutionary nihilism and ideological extremism in 19th-century Russia through a cast of radicals whose chaotic schemes lead to murder, suicide, and societal destruction.

books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.title: The Brothers Karamazov
books.about: Dostoevsky's final masterpiece follows the Karamazov brothers—sensual Dmitri, intellectual Ivan, spiritual Alyosha, and their depraved father—amid murder, faith, doubt, morality, free will, and the existence of God in a profound exploration of human nature and spirituality.

books.author: George Eliot
books.title: Middlemarch
books.about: A panoramic Victorian novel set in a provincial English town, intertwining multiple lives and stories to examine marriage, ambition, politics, science, reform, idealism, and the quiet tragedies of ordinary people in the years before the Reform Act of 1832.

books.author: Ralph Ellison
books.title: Invisible Man
books.about: A landmark African American novel following an unnamed narrator's journey from the rural South to Harlem, experiencing racism, betrayal, and disillusionment while grappling with identity, invisibility in society, and the search for self-definition.

books.author: Euripides
books.title: Medea
books.about: A powerful Greek tragedy depicting the betrayed sorceress Medea's revenge against her husband Jason, who abandons her for a new bride, exploring themes of passion, betrayal, gender, revenge, infanticide, and the clash between barbarian and Greek values.

books.author: William Faulkner
books.title: Absalom, Absalom!
books.about: A complex Southern Gothic novel reconstructing the tragic rise and fall of Thomas Sutpen's dynasty in Mississippi through multiple unreliable narrators, exploring race, class, history, the legacy of slavery, ambition, and the haunted American South.

books.author: William Faulkner
books.title: The Sound and the Fury
books.about: A modernist masterpiece using stream-of-consciousness to depict the decline of the Compson family in the American South through four sections narrated by different family members, including the mentally disabled Benjy, exploring time, memory, loss, and decay.

books.author: Gustave Flaubert
books.title: Madame Bovary
books.about: A realist novel chronicling the romantic delusions and adulterous affairs of Emma Bovary, a provincial doctor's wife seeking escape from boredom through fantasy and passion, leading to tragedy and critiquing bourgeois society, materialism, and romantic idealism.
